repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Energy Community
            of South East Europe (APL 3) Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Energy Community of
            South East Europe (APL 3) Program Project for Bosnia and
            Herzegovina were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: in projects with multiple co-financiers, parallel
            co-financing arrangements as against joint co-financing work
            better since delays in implementation of components of any
            financer do not adversely affect implementation of
            components financed by others. Parallel co-financing
            arrangements should not include any cross-effectiveness and
            cross-default clauses. Even intractable problems such as
            electricity theft, poor billing and collection can be solved
            if the power utility management pays sustained attention,
            sets clearly understood targets and enforces them with
            sanctions and rewards. In such a situation, involvement of
            external financiers can help address political economy
            constraints. Implementation schedules for generation
            rehabilitation projects should take into account the
            constraints in shutting down large generation units in
            relatively small systems for a long duration to carry out
            the rehabilitation. They should be made of discrete packages
            capable of being done during the regular planned shut down
            for maintenance (normally about three to four weeks). Even
            then delays could occur, as it did in Elektroprivereda
            Republika Srpska (EPRS), when the planned maintenance of
            thermal plants is postponed or curtailed due to poor
            hydrological conditions.

repnme.cdata!: A cleaner power grid in Bosnia and Herzegovina

abstracts.cdata!:
This result profile talks about power
            sector in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The Kakanj Power Plant
            Project has the following objectives: to rehabilitate and
            strengthen the power system in Southeastern Europe and to
            set up a regional electricity market. Bosnia and
            Herzegovina’s power infrastructure was badly damaged and its
            citizens disconnected from the regional grid. The project
            also aims to improve the environmental performance of four
            coal-fired power plants and improve the safety of dams in
            the country.

repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Energy Community
            of South East Europe (APL 3) Program Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the project is to
            facilitate Bosnia and Herzegovina's (BiH's)
            participation in Energy Community of South East Europe
            (ECSEE) through investments to: 1) improve dam safety; 2)
            reduce adverse environmental impacts at thermal power
            stations; 3) replace ageing existing facilities and
            equipment at hydropower and thermal power stations; 4)
            rehabilitate distribution systems and introduce distribution
            Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems; 5)
            establish a market operation system; and 6) provide hardware
            and software to improve the financial management information
            systems of the elektroprivredas. The project is to be
            restructured to allow Elektroprivreda of the Croatian
            Community of Herzeg-Bosnia (EPHZHB) to use savings of about
            SDR 110,000 for carrying out a study of solar energy
            potential in Herzegovina. EPHZHB is one of the three
            implementing agencies for the project. The project was
            restructured in November 2010 to extend the Closing Date to
            June 30, 2012 and reallocate the proceeds of International
            Development Association (IDA) credit among various
            disbursement categories. The request for use of savings
            could not be processed in November 2010 since the Bank had
            received a request only from EPHZHB but not from the
            Recipient, which has been since received.

display_title.display_title:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Energy
            Community of South East Europe (APL 3) Program Project :
            restructuring : Main report
